CorBin-FL: A Differentially Private Federated Learning Mechanism using Common Randomness

Hojat Allah Salehi1, Md Jueal Mia1, S. Sandeep Pradhan2, M. Hadi Amini1, Farhad Shirani1

1Knight Foundation School of Computing and Information Sciences,
Florida International University, Miami, FL, {hsalehi,mmia001,moamini,fshirani}@fiu.edu 2Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department
University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, pradhanv@umich.edu
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising framework for distributed machine learning. It enables collaborative learning among multiple clients, utilizing distributed data and computing resources. However, FL faces challenges in balancing privacy guarantees, communication efficiency, and overall model accuracy. In this work, we introduce CorBin-FL, a privacy mechanism that uses correlated binary stochastic quantization to achieve differential privacy while maintaining overall model accuracy. The approach uses secure multi-party computation techniques to enable clients to perform correlated quantization of their local model updates without compromising individual privacy. We provide theoretical analysis showing that CorBin-FL achieves parameter-level local differential privacy (PLDP), and that it asymptotically optimizes the privacy-utility trade-off between the mean square error utility measure and the PLDP privacy measure. We further propose AugCorBin-FL, an extension that, in addition to PLDP, achieves user-level and sample-level central differential privacy guarantees. For both mechanisms, we derive bounds on privacy parameters and mean squared error performance measures. Extensive experiments on MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets demonstrate that our mechanisms outperform existing differentially private FL mechanisms, including Gaussian and Laplacian mechanisms, in terms of model accuracy under equal PLDP privacy budgets111For reproducibility, our code is included in the supplementary material and will be made publicly available after publication..

I Introduction

Distributed stochastic gradient descent in general, and federated learning (FL) in particular, are foundational concepts in modern machine learning with wide-ranging applications [1, 2, 3]. The typical FL setup consists of a collection of distributed clients collaborating with a central server over multiple rounds of communication to train a global model. Each client is equipped with a local dataset. At each communication round, it receives a copy of the global model and updates it using local data. The updates, usually gradients, are sent to a server, which aggregates them and updates the global model. This enables privacy-preserving collaborative learning among multiple clients, utilizing distributed data and computing resources, without requiring the clients to disclose sensitive data. The latter property is of particular interest in sensitive applications such as training over health datasets [4, 5].

Federated learning inherently provides a degree of privacy by not requiring clients to share raw data. This is further enhanced when combined with secure aggregation techniques [6] which enable the clients to send the aggregate model to the server without revealing information about local update values. However, recent works have shown that both the aggregated model updates at each round and the final model weights may leak information about the training data, and even potentially enable the reconstruction of sensitive data [7, 8, 9, 10].

To provide quantifiable guarantees against data leakage, the concept of differential privacy (DP), introduced by [11], has emerged as a crucial framework. At a high level, DP requires that the output of an (aggregation) mechanism remains essentially unchanged when any single individual’s data is added to or removed from the input dataset. Several different notions of DP have been considered in FL. User-level central DP (UCDP) requires that the aggregate model at each round does not reveal the participation of any individual client in that round of training [12, 13, 14]. Sample-level central DP (SCDP) is more stringent and requires that the aggregate model does not reveal information about usage of any single training sample [15, 16]. Parameter-level local DP (PLDP) requires that an eavesdropper gaining access to the local update being transmitted by one of the clients in uplink communication does not gain information about each individual model parameter [17]. Prior works have considered injecting noise into the updates to achieve DP. These include the Gaussian mechanism, Laplacian mechanism, and the Discrete Gaussian mechanism, among others [18, 13, 19].

The communication cost of sending the gradients to the server often emerges as a performance bottleneck in FL. This is especially the case in scenarios where the clients are mobile devices with limited uplink bandwidth [20]. Recent works have focused on techniques such as gradient quantization to reduce the communication overhead [21, 22, 23]. In addition to gains in communication efficiency, quantization may yield improved privacy guarantees. A stochastic quantization method, called LDP-FL, was introduced in [17], which, in addition to reducing the communication overhead via one-bit quantization of each parameter update, guarantees PLDP. Alternative mechanisms adding discrete noise to quantized updates to achieve DP have also been considered, such as the binomial mechanism in [11, 20].

In this work, we consider correlated stochastic quantization to achieve various notions of DP, such as UCDP, SCDP, and PLDP. A key feature of our framework is that clients use shared common randomness to coordinate while maintaining privacy. To elaborate, at each communication round, the clients use the public channel facilitated by the server to exchange private keys using the Diffie-Hellman (DH) key exchange protocol [24]. The application of the DH protocol to construct pairwise secure communication among the clients has been previously explored in the literature, for instance the secure aggregation mechanism [6]. After exchanging private keys, clients are partitioned into pairs, and each pair uses their secure channel to share a few bits of common randomness per model parameter. The shared randomness is used to perform correlated stochastic quantization (Algorithm 2) of the model parameters, without requiring the clients to share any information about their respective model parameters. The quantizer is designed to achieve PLDP. Furthermore, the quantizer is unbiased and the quantization noises are correlated, such that they cancel each other in the aggregation phase, yielding small mean square error (MSE) between the aggregate of the quantized updates and that of the original local model updates. We refer to the resulting privacy mechanism, which uses correlated binary stochastic quantization, as the CorBin-FL mechanism. We also introduce the AugCorBin-FL mechanism, in which a fraction of the clients pair up and perform correlated quantization as in CorBin-FL, and the rest of the clients quantize their model weights individually. We show that the AugCorBin-FL mechanism achieves UCDP, SCDP, and PLDP and quantify the corresponding privacy parameters and achievable MSE. The idea of injecting correlated noise to achieve DP, via common randomness shared among pairs of clients, has been studied in two concurrent works, where the Gaussian mechanism was considered in FL [25] and general distributed mean estimation scenarios [26]. A main advantage of CorBin-FL is that it only requires a few bits of common randomness to be shared among the clients per model parameter to achieve close to optimal MSE (Theorem 1 and Figure 2(a)). This is in contrast with the aforementioned mechanisms which consider maximal negative correlation among Gaussian variables, that requires an asymptotically large number of common random bits per model parameter [27]. Our contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We introduce a privacy-utility tradeoff, in terms of the MSE utility measure and the PLDP privacy measure, and characterize the associated optimal class of binary stochastic quantizers. (Algorithm 1 and Proposition 1)

  • •

    We extend the formulation of the privacy-utility tradeoff to correlated stochastic pairs of quantizers, and provide an algorithm for asymptotically optimal correlated quantization. (Algorithm 2 and Theorem 1)

  • •

    We introduce the CorBin-FL mechanism (Algorithm 3), and provide privacy and utility guarantees in terms of PLDP and MSE. (Theorem 2)

  • •

    We introduce AugCorBin-FL and derive guarantees in terms of PLDP, UCDP, and MSE. (Theorem 3)

  • •

    We provide extensive empirical simulations demonstrating performance gains in terms of model accuracy under a fixed privacy budget over the Gaussian mechanism, the Laplacian mechanism, and LDP-FL, and other privacy mechanisms, on the MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets.

II Preliminaries

II-A Private Federated Learning

In this work, we propose privacy mechanisms and quantify their associated privacy gains when clients share a source of (limited) common randomness. The setting comprises n𝑛n clients, denoted by 𝒞i,i∈[n]subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{C}_{i},i\in[n], collaborating with a central server 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} to train a global model iteratively over multiple communication rounds. Each client 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} possesses a local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. At each communication round, the server sends the current global model to all clients, i.e., it sends the vector 𝐰g=(wg,j)j∈[m]subscript𝐰𝑔subscriptsubscript𝑤𝑔𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑚\mathbf{w}_{g}=(w_{g,j})_{j\in[m]}, where m𝑚m is the number of model parameters. The i𝑖ith client updates its local model based on 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and computes the updated local model parameters 𝐰i=(wi,j)j∈[m],i∈[n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐰𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑚𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathbf{w}_{i}=(w_{i,j})_{j\in[m]},i\in[n]. For any given j∈[m]𝑗delimited-[]𝑚j\in[m], let the bounded interval [cj−rj,cj+rj]subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑟𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑟𝑗[c_{j}-r_{j},c_{j}+r_{j}] be chosen such that it contains the collection of updated local model parameters, wi,j,i∈[n]subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑖delimited-[]𝑛w_{i,j},i\in[n]. The variable cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} is called the center and the variable rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j} the radius222 The center cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} and radius rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j} depend on the range of wi,j,i∈[n]subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑖delimited-[]𝑛w_{i,j},i\in[n]. In practice, the clients to do not have access to each other’s updated parameters. Consequently, the updated parameters are clipped by each client using a c^jsubscript^𝑐𝑗\hat{c}_{j} and r^jsubscript^𝑟𝑗\hat{r}_{j}, which are shared by the server at each round to ensure that wi,j∈[c^j−rj^,c^j+r^j]subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript^𝑐𝑗^subscript𝑟𝑗subscript^𝑐𝑗subscript^𝑟𝑗w_{i,j}\in[\hat{c}_{j}-\hat{r_{j}},\hat{c}_{j}+\hat{r}_{j}]. corresponding to the j𝑗jth model parameter. A key feature of our framework is that clients share a common vector of binary symmetric random variables 𝐙d×msuperscript𝐙𝑑𝑚\mathbf{Z}^{d\times m}, where d𝑑d is the number of shared bits per model parameter. We will describe the method to share this common vector among the clients in the subsequent sections. Clients apply a (possibly stochastic) privacy mechanism ℳ:ℝm×ℝd×m→ℝm:ℳ→superscriptℝ𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚superscriptℝ𝑚\mathcal{M}:\mathbb{R}^{m}\times\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{m}, generating the obfuscated vectors 𝐖¯i=ℳ​(𝐰i,𝐙d×m)subscript¯𝐖𝑖ℳsubscript𝐰𝑖superscript𝐙𝑑𝑚\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{i}=\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{w}_{i},\mathbf{Z}^{d\times m}), which are transmitted to the server. The server aggregates the obfuscated vectors, computing the updated parameters 𝐖¯g=1n​∑i∈[n]𝐖¯isubscript¯𝐖𝑔1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript¯𝐖𝑖\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{g}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{i}. The mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} should satisfy differential privacy constraints, as detailed in subsequent sections, while maintaining overall utility, in terms of the global model accuracy. In our theoretical derivations, the MSE between the aggregate of the obfuscated local updates and that of the unobfuscated updates is used as a surrogate utility measure. Our empirical evaluations show that the mechanism achieves improved accuracy over widely used methods such as the Gaussian and Laplacian mechanisms.

II-B Local and Central Differential Privacy

We consider the following notions of differential privacy.

II-B1 User-Level Central Differential Privacy:

For ϵu,δ>0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝛿0\epsilon_{u},\delta>0, a mechanism is said to achieve (ϵu,δ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝛿(\epsilon_{u},\delta)-UCDP if:

where 𝐖¯g=1n​∑i=1n𝐖¯isubscript¯𝐖𝑔1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript¯𝐖𝑖\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{g}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{i},𝐖¯g′=1n​∑i=2n𝐖¯isubscriptsuperscript¯𝐖′𝑔1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑛subscript¯𝐖𝑖\overline{\mathbf{W}}^{\prime}_{g}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=2}^{n}\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{i}, 𝐖¯i=ℳ​(𝐰i,𝐙d×m),𝐰i∈ℝmformulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐖𝑖ℳsubscript𝐰𝑖superscript𝐙𝑑𝑚subscript𝐰𝑖superscriptℝ𝑚\overline{\mathbf{W}}_{i}=\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{{w}}_{i},\mathbf{Z}^{{d\times m}}),\mathbf{{w}}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}, and 𝒯⊆ℝm𝒯superscriptℝ𝑚\mathcal{T}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{m}. At a high level, this condition guarantees that an adversary having access to the updated aggregate model weights cannot reliably detect if a specific user has participated in the training round.

II-B3 Parameter-Level Local Differential Privacy:

This guarantees the privacy of each local model parameter if the uplink communication between client and server is compromised.

II-C The LDP-FL Mechanism

In the subsequent sections, we build upon the LDP-FL mechanism [17] to introduce the CorBin-FL and AugCorBin-FL privacy mechanisms. For completeness, we provide a brief summary of the LDP-FL mechanism in this section. For a fixed ϵp>0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝0\epsilon_{p}>0, the mechanism uses a stochastic quantizer, denoted by LDPQ​(⋅)LDPQ⋅\textsc{LDPQ}(\cdot), to obfuscate each of the local model parameters. The LDPQ​(⋅)LDPQ⋅\textsc{LDPQ}(\cdot) quantizer is described in Algorithm 1. To provide an overview, given an input weight w𝑤w, center c𝑐c, and radius r𝑟r, the quantizer produces a binary random variable U𝑈U with

P​(U=1)=1−P​(U=−1)=12+w−c2​r​α​(ϵp),𝑃𝑈11𝑃𝑈112𝑤𝑐2𝑟𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝P(U=1)=1-P(U=-1)=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{w-c}{2r\alpha(\epsilon_{p})},

where α​(ϵp)=1+eϵp1−eϵp𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\alpha(\epsilon_{p})=\frac{1+e^{\epsilon_{p}}}{1-e^{\epsilon_{p}}}. Each client computes W¯i,j=L​D​P​Q​(ϵp,cj,rj,wi,j),j∈[m]formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝑊𝑖𝑗𝐿𝐷𝑃𝑄subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑟𝑗subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑚\overline{W}_{i,j}=LDPQ(\epsilon_{p},c_{j},r_{j},w_{i,j}),j\in[m] and sends it to the server.

To gain insights into the operation of LDP-FL, let us consider a scenario with no privacy requirements, i.e., ϵp→∞→subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}\to\infty. Then, α​(ϵp)→1→𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1\alpha(\epsilon_{p})\to 1 and if wi,j>cjsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗{w}_{i,j}>c_{j}, then P​(U=1)>P​(U=−1)𝑃𝑈1𝑃𝑈1P(U=1)>P(U=-1), i.e., it is more likely that the client sends the update W¯i,j=cj+rjsubscript¯𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑟𝑗\overline{W}_{i,j}=c_{j}+r_{j}. Conversely, if wi,j<cjsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗{w}_{i,j}<c_{j}, then it is more likely that it sends the update W¯i,j=cj−rjsubscript¯𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑟𝑗\overline{W}_{i,j}=c_{j}-r_{j}. This can be interpreted as the client sending the direction of change, rather than the actual value of the updated model parameter.

As the privacy budget ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} is decreased, the client update becomes less truthful, i.e., it becomes more likely that U𝑈U points to the direction opposite to the true update direction. On average, the misdirections of different clients average out since the mechanism produces an unbiased estimate, and the aggregate update on the server-side remains accurate. To see this, note that from Line 4 in Algorithm 1, we have 𝔼​(U)=wi,j2​rj​α​(ϵp)𝔼𝑈subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗2subscript𝑟𝑗𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\mathbb{E}(U)=\frac{{w}_{i,j}}{2r_{j}\alpha(\epsilon_{p})}, so that 𝔼​(W¯i,j)=wi,j𝔼subscript¯𝑊𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗\mathbb{E}(\overline{W}_{i,j})={w}_{i,j}. When the number of participating clients is sufficiently large, the unbiased property ensures that the aggregate of the obfuscated parameters closely approximates that of the original, unobfuscated inputs. The MSE of the parameter estimate is 𝔼​((W¯g,j−wg,j)2)≈rj2​α2​(ϵp)n𝔼superscriptsubscript¯𝑊𝑔𝑗subscript𝑤𝑔𝑗2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑗2superscript𝛼2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑛\mathbb{E}((\overline{W}_{g,j}-w_{g,j})^{2})\approx\frac{r_{j}^{2}\alpha^{2}(\epsilon_{p})}{n} [17, Lemma 3], and vanishes as n𝑛n becomes asymptotically large.

III Correlated Stochastic Quantizers

In this section, we introduce a novel class of correlated stochastic quantizers. We first show that the LDPQ quantizer is the solution to a specific privacy-utility optimization. Then, we build on this to construct the maximally correlated distributed quantizers which are used in the CorBin-FL and AugCorBin-FL mechanisms in the subsequent sections.

III-A Optimality of the LDPQ Stochastic Quantizer

Given c,r>0𝑐𝑟0c,r>0, a binary-output stochastic quantizer is a (stochastic) mapping Q:[c−r,c+r]→{γ1,γ2}:𝑄→𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2Q:[c\!-\!r,c\!+\!r]\to\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}\}, where γ1,γ2∈ℝsubscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2ℝ\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}\in\mathbb{R}. We quantify privacy in terms of PLDP and utility in terms of the output bias and the MSE. To elaborate, for a given ϵp>0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝0\epsilon_{p}>0, we say the quantizer optimizes the privacy-utility tradeoff if the following conditions are satisfied:

  1. C1.

    Unbiasedness: 𝔼​(Q​(w))=w𝔼𝑄𝑤𝑤\mathbb{E}(Q(w))\!=\!{w} for all w∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w\in[c\!-\!r,c\!+\!r],

  2. C2.

    ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}-PLDP: P​(Q​(w)=w¯)P​(Q​(w′)=w¯)≤eϵp𝑃𝑄𝑤¯𝑤𝑃𝑄superscript𝑤′¯𝑤superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\frac{P(Q(w)=\overline{w})}{P(Q(w^{\prime})=\overline{w})}\leq e^{\epsilon_{p}} for all w¯∈{γ1,γ2}¯𝑤subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2\overline{w}\in\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}\} and w,w′∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w,w^{\prime}\in[c-r,c+r].

  3. C3.

    Minimal MSE: 𝔼​((Q​(w)−w)2)𝔼superscript𝑄𝑤𝑤2\mathbb{E}((Q(w)-w)^{2}) is minimized for all w∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w\in[c-r,c+r].

The following proposition shows that the LDPQ quantizer uniquely satisfies conditions C1-C3.

Proposition 1.

Let c,r,ϵp>0𝑐𝑟subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝0c,r,\epsilon_{p}>0. The binary-output quantizer Q​(w)=L​D​P​Q​(ϵp,c,r,w),w∈[c−r,c+r]formulae-sequence𝑄𝑤𝐿𝐷𝑃𝑄subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑐𝑟𝑤𝑤𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟Q(w)=LDPQ(\epsilon_{p},c,r,w),w\in[c-r,c+r] in Algorithm 1 is the unique quantizer satisfying conditions C1-C3.

The proof is provided in the technical appendix included with the supplementary material.

III-B Correlated Stochastic Quantization

In the next step, we consider the distributed quantization of a pair of inputs w,w′𝑤superscript𝑤′w,w^{\prime} when the pair of clients have access to a shared sequence of common random bits. To elaborate, let us assume that the clients have access to a sequence of binary symmetric random variables 𝐙=(Z1,Z2,⋯,Zd)𝐙subscript𝑍1subscript𝑍2⋯subscript𝑍𝑑\mathbf{Z}=(Z_{1},Z_{2},\cdots,Z_{d}) for a fixed d∈ℕ𝑑ℕd\in\mathbb{N}. We wish to design a pair of stochastic quantizers Qi:[c−r,c+r]×{0,1}d→{γ1,γ2},i∈{1,2}:subscript𝑄𝑖formulae-sequence→𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟superscript01𝑑subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2𝑖12Q_{i}:[c-r,c+r]\times\{0,1\}^{d}\to\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}\},i\in\{1,2\}, satisfying the following conditions:

  1. C4.

    Unbiased Output: 𝔼​(Q1​(w),𝐙)=w,𝔼​(Q2​(w′),𝐙)=w′formulae-sequence𝔼subscript𝑄1𝑤𝐙𝑤𝔼subscript𝑄2superscript𝑤′𝐙superscript𝑤′\mathbb{E}(Q_{1}(w),\mathbf{Z})=w,\mathbb{E}(Q_{2}(w^{\prime}),\mathbf{Z})\!=\!w^{\prime} for all w,w′∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w,w^{\prime}\in[c-r,c+r].

  2. C5.

    ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}-PLDP: P​(Qi​(w,𝐙)=w¯)P​(Qi​(w′,𝐙)=w¯)≤eϵp𝑃subscript𝑄𝑖𝑤𝐙¯𝑤𝑃subscript𝑄𝑖superscript𝑤′𝐙¯𝑤superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\frac{P(Q_{i}(w,\mathbf{Z})=\overline{w})}{P(Q_{i}(w^{\prime},\mathbf{Z})=\overline{w})}\leq e^{\epsilon_{p}} for all w¯∈{γ1,γ2}¯𝑤subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2\overline{w}\in\{\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}\}, w,w′∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w,w^{\prime}\in[c-r,c+r], and i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\in\{1,2\}.

  3. C6.

    Minimal MSE: 𝔼​((Q1​(w,𝐙)+Q2​(w′,𝐙)−w−w′)2)𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑄1𝑤𝐙subscript𝑄2superscript𝑤′𝐙𝑤superscript𝑤′2\mathbb{E}((Q_{1}(w,\mathbf{Z})+Q_{2}(w^{\prime},\mathbf{Z})-w-w^{\prime})^{2}) is minimized for all w,w′∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w,w^{\prime}\in[c-r,c+r].

The pair of stochastic quantizers used in CorBin-FL, denoted by CorBinQ are described in Algorithm 2. In the sequel, we show that the pair satisfies conditions C4-C5 for all d∈ℕ𝑑ℕd\in\mathbb{N}, and condition C6 asymptotically as d→∞→𝑑d\to\infty. To provide an overview, the CorBinQ quantizers described in Algorithm 2 takes parameters ϵp,r,c>0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑟𝑐0\epsilon_{p},r,c>0, weights w,w′∈[c−r,c+r]𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w,w^{\prime}\in[c-r,c+r], and a shared sequence of independent binary symmetric random variables 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} as input. It then constructs a pair of threshold vectors 𝐓1subscript𝐓1\mathbf{T}_{1} and 𝐓2subscript𝐓2\mathbf{T}_{2} as described in Line 3 of the algorithm, where Bd​(⋅)subscript𝐵𝑑⋅B_{d}(\cdot) denotes the d-bit decimal to binary operator. The quantization process involves comparing the shared random sequence 𝐙𝐙\mathbf{Z} with these threshold vectors using lexicographic ordering (≺precedes\prec). To elaborate, as described in Lines 4-11 of the algorithm, the first quantizer, Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1}, outputs c+r​α​(ϵp)𝑐𝑟𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝c+r\alpha(\epsilon_{p}) if 𝐙≺𝐓1precedes𝐙subscript𝐓1\mathbf{Z}\prec\mathbf{T}_{1} and c−r​α​(ϵp)𝑐𝑟𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝c-r\alpha(\epsilon_{p}) if 𝐓1≺𝐙precedessubscript𝐓1𝐙\mathbf{T}_{1}\prec\mathbf{Z}. Ties are resolved using a locally generated binary random variable U𝑈U with bias 2d​q1−⌊2d​q1⌋superscript2𝑑subscript𝑞1superscript2𝑑subscript𝑞12^{d}q_{1}-\lfloor 2^{d}q_{1}\rfloor, as described in Lines 9-10. The design of 𝐓isubscript𝐓𝑖\mathbf{T}_{i} and the tie-breaking rule ensures that the marginal distribution of the output of each Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} matches that of the stochastic quantizer used in LDP-FL. Thus, satisfying the unbiasedness and ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}-PLDP conditions. Furthermore, Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} and Q2subscript𝑄2Q_{2} produce outputs based on reverse lexicographic ordering relative to each other. This guarantees maximum negative correlation between the quantizers, which minimizes the resulting MSE.

IV CorBin-FL and AugCorBin-FL Mechanisms

IV-1 The CorBin-FL Mechanism:

IV-2 Privacy-Utility Guarantees:

IV-3 The Augmented CorBin-FL Mechanism:

So far, we have shown that CorBin-FL is unbiased, achieves ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}-PLDP, and improves upon LDP-FL in terms of MSE. In addition to PLDP, the CorBin-FL mechanism can be modified to achieve UCDP and SCDP. To elaborate, let γ∈[0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1] and consider a mechanism where, at each round, γ𝛾\gamma fraction of the clients use the LDP-FL mechanism to obfuscate their corresponding weights, and (1−γ)1𝛾(1-\gamma) fraction use the CorBin-FL mechanism. We call the resulting mechanism, which is a hybrid mechanism between LDP-FL and CorBin-FL, the AugCorBin-FL mechanism. The following theorem prides the UCDP guarantees and an upper-bound on the mean square error resulting from the AugCorBin-FL mechanism.

IV-4 Robustness to Client Dropout:

The CorBin-FL mechanism is robust to client dropouts. The reason is that if a member of a pair of clients drops out, the quantization performed by the other client is equivalent to the LDPQ quantizer. In fact, if a lower-bound to the dropout probability of each individual client is known, and if the clients dropout independently of each other, then one can derive additional central differential privacy guarantees for the resulting mechanism. This is made precise in the following theorem.

Theorem 4.

Then, the CorBin-FL mechanism achieves ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}-PLDP and (ϵu,δ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢𝛿(\epsilon_{u},\delta)-UCDP, where, ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} is given by Equation (5). Furthermore, the mean square error is bounded by:

The proof is provided in the technical appendix.

IV-5 Communication Cost:

The server broadcasts the global model to all clients, which requires 𝒪​(32​m)𝒪32𝑚\mathcal{O}(32m) bits of downlink communication, assuming 32-bit floating-point representation. Subsequently, the DH key exchange protocol is used to enable pairwise secure communication among clients. The DH protocol has uplink and downlink communication cost of 𝒪​(n​k)𝒪𝑛𝑘\mathcal{O}(nk) bits per client, where k𝑘k represents the DH key size [24]. Then, the leaders in each pair of clients generate a d𝑑d-length binary symmetric random vector, and encrypt and transmit the vector to the follow, which requires 𝒪​(d​m​k)𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑘\mathcal{O}(dmk) bits of uplink and downlink communication. Each client applies CorBinQ and uploads the quantized updated model to the server, with 𝒪​(m)𝒪𝑚\mathcal{O}(m) bits of uplink communication. The aggregate communication complexity per round is 𝒪​(d​m​k+n​k)𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑘𝑛𝑘\mathcal{O}(dmk+nk). Typically, the number of model parameters m𝑚m dominates the number of clients n𝑛n. Consequently, the communication cost is 𝒪​(d​m​k)𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑘\mathcal{O}(dmk).

Computation Cost: The computation cost of the DH key exchange protocol is 𝒪​(n​k2​log⁡k)𝒪𝑛superscript𝑘2𝑘\mathcal{O}(nk^{2}\log k). For generating d​m𝑑𝑚dm binary symmetric random variables, the cost is 𝒪​(d​m)𝒪𝑑𝑚\mathcal{O}(dm), and the encryption and computational complexity of CorBinQ in Algorithm 2 consisting of a lexicographic binary vector comparison and the generation of a binary random variable is 𝒪​(m)𝒪𝑚\mathcal{O}(m) per client. In total the computation complexity is 𝒪(dm+nk2logk\mathcal{O}(dm+nk^{2}\log k).

V Empirical Analysis

V-1 Experimental Setup:

We empirically evaluate the performance of the proposed privacy mechanisms over a series of experiments as outlined in the sequel. To provide an overview, our objective is to demonstrate that i) under a fixed privacy budget and number of communication rounds, the proposed mechanisms outperform the LDP-FL, and Gaussian and Laplace Mechanisms in terms of overall model accuracy (Figure 1), ii) the accuracy gains increase as the number of shared random bits per model parameter is increased, however, the gains saturate for relatively small values of d𝑑d (e.g., d=5𝑑5d=5) as predicted in Theorem 1 (Figure 2(a)), iii) the proposed methods are robust to client dropouts, and the model accuracy does not fall significantly even for large dropout probabilities, e.g., for p=0.5𝑝0.5p=0.5 (Figure 2(b)), and iv) the proposed methods outperform the LDP-FL mechanism for different numbers of clients ranging from 50 to 500 (Figure 2(c)). A detailed description of the experimental setup is provided in this section. Further empirical evaluations and ablation studies are included in the technical appendix.

V-2 Datasets and Models:

Experiments are over the MNIST [29] and CIFAR10 [30] datasets. The samples are split randomly, with 80%percent8080\% of the samples used for training and the remaining samples for testing. We choose 20% of the training samples randomly for validation. We consider an IID data distribution setting, where each client receives an equal fraction of the samples randomly and without replacement. The batch size is 64 for all experiments except for Figure 2(c), where it is taken to be 32 due to the large numbers of clients which yields a smaller per-client dataset size. We use the ResNet18 [31] model for experiments over the CIFAR10 dataset and small (two-layers) VGG [32] model for experiments over the MNIST dataset. The number of shared random bits per parameter is d=5𝑑5d=5 and the AugCorBin-FL parameter is taken as γ=0.2𝛾0.2\gamma=0.2 across all experiments unless specified otherwise. The center and radius are shared by the server at each round based on the layer-wise minimum and maximum parameter values in the previous round. The experiments are performed on a single NVIDIA A100-PCIE-40GB GPU.

V-3 Smoothed Update Rule and Checkpoints:

We include a global learning rate hyperparatmer λ𝜆\lambda. At each communication round, let 𝐰g,i​n​i​tsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡\mathbf{w}_{g,init} be the initial global parameter vector, and 𝐰g,f​i​n​a​lsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑓𝑖𝑛𝑎𝑙\mathbf{w}_{g,final} the updated parameter vector at the end of the communication round. We update the model as follows:

𝐰g=(1−λ)​𝐰g,i​n​i​t+λ​𝐰g,f​i​n​a​lsubscript𝐰𝑔1𝜆subscript𝐰𝑔𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡𝜆subscript𝐰𝑔𝑓𝑖𝑛𝑎𝑙\mathbf{w}_{g}=(1-\lambda)\mathbf{w}_{g,init}+\lambda\mathbf{w}_{g,final} (6)

Taking λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 reduces to the original update rule without the inclusion of the global learning rate hyperparameter. For each experiment, and for all privacy mechanisms, we preform a grid search over λ∈{0.1,0.2,…,1}𝜆0.10.2…1\lambda\in\{0.1,0.2,...,1\}. We also implement a check-pointing mechanism with a patience of five epochs, so that the model is reloaded if the validation accuracy does not increase over five epochs.

V-4 Experiment 1 - Comparison of Privacy Mechanisms:

We train an FL model over CIFAR-10 for 50 clients, with a PLDP budget of ϵp=5subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝5\epsilon_{p}=5 using the Gaussian, Laplacian, LPD-FL, CorBin-FL, and AugCorBin-FL mechanisms. For the Gaussian mechanism, we find the noise variance using the bound in [33]. The Laplace mechanism is implemented according to [34]. Figure 1 shows the resulting accuracy gains. To provide further baselines for comparison, we have implemented the vanilla-FL with no privacy guarantees. An advantage of CorBin-FL and AugCorBin-FL over other mechanisms is the low communication cost due to one-bit quantization of the model parameters. Thus, to provide another baseline, we have implemented the correlated quantization (CQ) method of [35] which does not provide piracy guarantees but reduces the communication cost via quantization.

V-5 Experiment 2 - Effects of the Number of Shared Random Bits

Under the same settings as the previous experiment and with ϵp=1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1\epsilon_{p}=1, we evaluate the performance of CorBin-FL under various number of shared random bits per model paramter, d∈{3,5,7}𝑑357d\in\{3,5,7\}. The results are shown in Figure 2(a).

V-6 Experiment 3 - Effects of Dropout:

Under the same settings as the previous experiment, we have evaluated the effect of random client dropout on the performance of CorBin-FL. As shown in Figure 2(b), the performance does not fall significantly even when the client randomly and independently dropout at each round with 50%percent5050\% probability.

V-7 Experiment 4 - Effect of the Number of Clients:

We have evaluated the performance of LDP-FL, CorBin-FL with privacy budget ϵp=5subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝5\epsilon_{p}=5, and Vanilla-FL without privacy guarantees. The results are shown in Figure 2(c). It can be observed that CorBin-FL consistently outperforms LDP-FL given a fixed privacy budget over a range of client numbers.

VI Conclusion and Future Works

The CorBin-FL and AugCorBin-FL mechanisms were introduced for differentially private federated learning. These approaches, which are based on correlated binary stochastic quantization, were shown to achieve various notions of differential privacy. Theoretical guarantees for privacy parameters and mean squared error were derived. Empirical evaluations on MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets demonstrated improved model accuracy compared to existing methods under equal PLDP privacy budgets. In future works, we will investigate the extension of the proposed methods to correlated quantizers with larger output alphabets, and correlated quantization among collections of more than two clients.

This completes the proof. ∎

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 1

Appendix E Proof of Theorem 4

Then,

P​(∑i∈[n]Fi∈[θ​n,θ′​n])≥1−(δ−δ1),𝑃subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃𝑛superscript𝜃′𝑛1𝛿subscript𝛿1\displaystyle P(\sum_{i\in[n]}F_{i}\in[\theta n,\theta^{\prime}n])\geq 1-(\delta-\delta_{1}),

where θ=p​(1−p)−p​(1−p)(δ−δ1)​n𝜃𝑝1𝑝𝑝1𝑝𝛿subscript𝛿1𝑛\theta=p(1-p)-\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{(\delta-\delta_{1})n}} and θ′=p​(1−p)+p​(1−p)(δ−δ1)​nsuperscript𝜃′𝑝1𝑝𝑝1𝑝𝛿subscript𝛿1𝑛\theta^{\prime}=p(1-p)+\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{(\delta-\delta_{1})n}}. Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be the event that ∑i∈[n]Fi∈[θ​n,θ′​n]subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃𝑛superscript𝜃′𝑛\sum_{i\in[n]}F_{i}\in[\theta n,\theta^{\prime}n], then:

limd→∞𝔼​((W¯g,j−1N​∑i:Fi=1wi,j)2)subscript→𝑑𝔼superscriptsubscript¯𝑊𝑔𝑗1𝑁subscript:𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖1subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗2\displaystyle\lim_{d\to\infty}\mathbb{E}((\overline{{W}}_{g,j}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i:F_{i}=1}{w}_{i,j})^{2})

≤(1−γ)2​n​θ​r2​((2−1)​α​(ϵp)+1)​((2+1)​α​(ϵp)−1)+γ′​r2​α2​(ϵp)n​θ+8​r2​α2​(ϵp)​δ1.absent1𝛾2𝑛𝜃superscript𝑟221𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝121𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝1superscript𝛾′superscript𝑟2superscript𝛼2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝𝑛𝜃8superscript𝑟2superscript𝛼2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝subscript𝛿1\displaystyle\leq\frac{(1-\gamma)}{2n\theta}r^{2}\left((\sqrt{2}-1)\alpha(\epsilon_{p})+1\right)\left((\sqrt{2}+1)\alpha(\epsilon_{p})-1\right)+\frac{\gamma^{\prime}r^{2}\alpha^{2}(\epsilon_{p})}{n\theta}+8r^{2}\alpha^{2}(\epsilon_{p})\delta_{1}.

This completes the proof. ∎

Appendix F Additional Experimental Results

In this section, we provide additional empirical evaluations and experimental results to evaluate various aspects of the proposed privacy mechanisms in comparison with existing mechanisms.

F-1 Experiment 5 - Correlated quantization without privacy constraints:

An advantage of CorBin-FL is the low communication cost due to one-bit quantization of each model parameter. Other works have considered correlated quantization without privacy constraints and towards reducing the communication overhead. In this experiment, we take the correlated quantization (CQ) method of [35] as a representative example, and compare its accuracy performance with that of CorBin-FL and LDP-FL when ϵp=10subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝10\epsilon_{p}=10, i.e. very weak privacy constraints. We perform the simulation over the CIFAR-10 dataset, as illustrated in Figure 3(a). The experiment involves 50 clients in a federated learning setting, with a batch size of 64. For CorBin-FL, we set the PLDP budget to ϵp=10subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝10\epsilon_{p}=10 and use d=5𝑑5d=5 common random bits. The global learning rate hyperparameter λ𝜆\lambda equal to one for all methods. We include one-bit correlated quantization method [35] without privacy guarantees, as well as LDP-FL with a significantly relaxed privacy budget of ϵp=50subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝50\epsilon_{p}=50 for comparison. The results demonstrate that CorBin-FL with ϵp=10subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝10\epsilon_{p}=10 achieves accuracy that is almost equal to that of the CQ with ϵp→∞→subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}\to\infty and LDP-FL with ϵp=50subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝50\epsilon_{p}=50.

F-2 Experiment 6 - Accuracy for Varying Privacy Budgets:

We evaluate the accuracy performance of CorBin-FL, AugCorBin-FL, and LDP-FL on the CIFAR10 dataset, considering various privacy budgets ϵp∈{1,3,5}subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝135\epsilon_{p}\in\{1,3,5\}. We perform a grid search over λ∈{0.1,0.2,…,1.0}𝜆0.10.2…1.0\lambda\in\{0.1,0.2,...,1.0\} for each value of ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}. Figure 3(b) presents the best accuracy achieved by each method for the different privacy budgets.

F-3 Experiment 7- Experiments on the MNIST Dataset:

We conduct experiments on the MNIST dataset with a fixed privacy budget of ϵp=0.5subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝0.5\epsilon_{p}=0.5 and using a two-layer VGG model. We compare the performance of CorBin-FL, LDP-FL, and the Vanilla-FL with no privacy guarantees. We perform a grid search over λ∈{0.1,0.2,…,1.0}𝜆0.10.2…1.0\lambda\in\{0.1,0.2,...,1.0\} for all methods to ensure fair comparison, the result is shown in Figure 3(c). The results demonstrate that CorBin-FL achieves better accuracy compared to LDP-FL and the gap becomes larger for smaller values of epsilon. The accuracy loss of CorBin-FL compared to vanilla-FL is less than 1.5% at ϵp=0.5subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝0.5\epsilon_{p}=0.5.

F-4 Experiment 8 - MSE comparison of LDPQ and CorBinQ:

We focus on the quantizers used in the CorBin-FL and LDP-FL mechanisms, namely the CorBinQ and LDPQ quantizers. We plot the resulting MSE when feeding a pair of quantziers with two input weights w1,w2∈[c−r,c+r]subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2𝑐𝑟𝑐𝑟w_{1},w_{2}\in[c-r,c+r], where we have taken c=0𝑐0c=0 and r=0.5𝑟0.5r=0.5. Figure 4 show the MSE comparison between a pair of clients utilizing CorBinQ in Algorithm 2 and a pair of clients using the LDPQ in Algorithm 1. The figure demonstrates the MSE gains of CorBinQ, particularly at smaller values of the privacy budget ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}. There is a larger gap in variance between CorBinQ and LDPQ methods as ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} decreases. This suggests that correlated randomness is especially beneficial in scenarios requiring stronger privacy guarantees (i.e., smaller ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} values).
